Black-footed Albatross: Seabird with contrasting black and white plumage
Features a distinctive long, hooked bill ideal for its carnivorous diet
Laysan Albatross: Has a sturdy body adapted to the challenges of oceanic life
A predominantly white seabird with black wingtips
Sooty Albatross: Employs long, narrow wings for efficient soaring across vast ocean distances
Webbed feet support its aquatic lifestyle
Groove-billed Ani: Adapted to diverse habitats from the southern United States to Mexico
Features a sleek black plumage with a notable white stripe above the eyes
Crested Auklet: Black bill sharply contrasts with its plumage, aiding in prey capture
Utilizes its black bill for feeding in marine environments
Least Auklet: Black wings feature distinctive white spots
Compact black and white bird with notable white ring around its black eyes
Parakeet Auklet: Employs a short, black tail for maneuvering in tight coastal niches
Black back and wings with white underside for thermal regulation
Rhinoceros Auklet: Characterized by a large, bulbous bill, resembling that of a rhinoceros
Short, stubby tail and webbed feet are well-adapted for marine life
Brewer Blackbird: Equipped with a long, curved beak for foraging seeds and insects
Displays black wings with white spots
Red-winged Blackbird: Well-adapted to marsh and wetland environments
Characterized by striking red and yellow wing markings on a black body
Rusty Blackbird: Black bill and legs complement its overall dark appearance
Yellow eyes pierce through its darker plumage, creating a striking visual
Yellow-headed Blackbird: Showcases a bright yellow head and chest, creating a stark contrast with its black body
Features a bright yellow head and distinct yellow wing patches
Bobolink: Features a striking white collar against a black underside.
Displays a distinctively long black tail.
Indigo Bunting: Black wings and tail accentuate its blue plumage.
Males display intense blue during breeding season.
Lazuli Bunting: Females and juveniles are muted in color, with a streaked breast.
Male plumage transitions from blue to orange on the breast.
Painted Bunting: Known for its kaleidoscopic plumage of blue, green, and red.
Short, stout bill for seed consumption.
Cardinal: Features a distinctive crest on top of its head.
Notably vocal, with a variety of songs and calls.
Spotted Catbird: Exhibits a long, black tail utilized in territorial display.
Features a black head with distinctive white spots on the side
Gray Catbird: Equipped with a long, black beak
Slate grey bird with a black cap and tail, accented by a white belly
Yellow-breasted Chat: Notable for its large size among North American warblers.
Equipped with a black bill suitable for its insectivorous diet
Eastern Towhee: Females and juveniles are brown where males are black.
Inhabits brushy and forested areas across Eastern North America
Chuck-will Widow: Notable for its nightjar song, repeating 'Chuck-will's-widow'.
Exhibits long wings and a wide, gaping mouth for feeding.
Brandt Cormorant: Utilizes wings to 'fly' underwater while hunting fish.
Long, hooked bill effective for catching and holding slippery prey.
Red-faced Cormorant: Dark plumage contrasts with striking red facial skin.
Feathers not fully waterproof, seen spreading wings to dry.
Pelagic Cormorant: Flight is low over the water with rapid wing beats.
Nests on sheer cliff faces near water
Bronzed Cowbird: Displays a bronzed iridescence on black plumage.
Prefers open or semi-open habitats, often seen near livestock.
Shiny Cowbird: Inclined to brood parasitism, impacting populations of host species.
Brown Creeper: Small, brown bird with camouflaged plumage for tree-bark blending
Spirals upward around tree trunks in search of insects.
American Crow: Omnivorous diet includes invertebrates, seeds, and waste.
Known for its intelligence and complex social behaviors
Fish Crow: Coastal bird, feeds on fish and crustaceans as well as garbage
Resembles the American Crow but with a more slender body and distinct call
Black-billed Cuckoo: Slim, long-tailed bird with brownish-gray upperparts
White underparts with thin, black bill
Mangrove Cuckoo: Yellow-bellied with a gray face and brown upperparts
Inhabits mangroves and dense woodlands, elusive
Yellow-billed Cuckoo: Distinguished by its long, curved beak and black-and-white tail
Long, slender bird with brown back, white belly, and yellow bill
Gray-crowned-Rosy Finch: Bulky nest often placed on ground or low in bushes
Purple Finch: Breeds in coniferous and mixed forests
Conical bill for seed and fruit eating
Northern Flicker: Feeds on ground, mainly ants and beetles
Nests in tree cavities, often excavated by the bird itself
Acadian Flycatcher: Catches insects in mid-air with agile, fluttering flight
Olive green upperparts, white underparts, and pale eye-ring
Great-Crested Flycatcher: Nests in tree cavities, may use snake skin in nest lining
Least Flycatcher: Grayish-olive upperparts, white underparts, and distinct eye-ring
Olive-sided Flycatcher: Hunts flying insects from high perches, sallies out for prey
Inhabits forested areas, often perching high to hunt for insects
Scissor-tailed Flycatcher: Pale gray body, strikingly long, forked tail, and salmon-pink flanks
Recognizable by its long, forked tail and contrasting black and white plumage
Vermilion Flycatcher: Catches insects in midair with sally flights
Distinctive song is a series of sweet, clear phrases
Yellow-bellied Flycatcher: Breeds in wet, northern forests, often near water
Frigatebird: Large seabird with a distinctive red gular sac and deeply forked tail
Known as the 'pirate bird' for its kleptoparasitic behavior
Northern Fulmar: Seabird with a long wingspan, webbed feet, and distinctive hooked bill
Feeds primarily at sea, known to follow ships
Gadwall: Prefers freshwater lakes, marshes, and ponds
Drabber than other ducks, males have a neat black rear end
American Goldfinch: Males bright yellow with black forehead in summer
Small, sparrow-like bird with vibrant yellow and black plumage
European Goldfinch: Features a red face and black and white head
Nests are compact and neat, with a foundation of twigs lined with wool and hair
Boat-tailed Grackle: Omnivorous, eating insects, grain, small vertebrates, and food waste
Favors salt marshes, coastal areas, but often found in city parks and suburban areas
Eared Grebe: Aquatic, excellent diver, feeds on aquatic insects and fish
Performs elaborate mating dances and displays
Horned Grebe: Small and compact, with a steep forehead and a short, pointed bill
Pied-billed Grebe: Small waterbird with a unique bill pattern and webbed feet for diving
Often heard before seen, emitting a peculiar, whinnying call
Western Grebe: Large, elegant with a long, swan-like neck and striking black-and-white plumage
Feeds primarily on fish, captured with diving
Blue Grosbeak: Inhabits shrubby areas and open woodlands, often near water

Evening Grosbeak: Large, stocky finch with a robust, conical bill
Frequents sunflower feeders in winter, often in large, noisy flocks
Pine Grosbeak: Large, chunky finch with rounded head and thick bill
Gentle, mellow call, often forming loose flocks outside of breeding season
Rose-breasted Grosbeak: Exhibits a striking color contrast with its namesake rose breast patch
Pigeon Guillemot: Nests in crevices and burrows on rocky coastlines
Dives for fish and invertebrates, uses wings to 'fly' underwater
California Gull: Versatile feeder: eats insects, fish, eggs, and garbage

Glaucous-winged Gull: Bright yellow beak with a subtle red dot on the lower part
Large gull with a uniform grey wing pattern and a yellow bill
Heermann Gull: Characterized by its uniform grey body and a distinctive red spot on its bill
Herring Gull: Wide-ranging, inhabits coastal and inland areas
Ivory Gull: Small, dainty stature with a plump body
Eyes like drops of golden honey
Ring-billed Gull: Common across North America, often found in inland and coastal areas
Clean white body with a graceful gray back
Slaty-backed Gull: Back and wings painted in a dusky shade of slate gray
Robust body with a thickset neck
Western Gull: Large bird known for its loud, raucous calls and aggressive behavior
Feeds on fish, marine invertebrates, and by scavenging
Anna Hummingbird: Tiny frame capable of agile mid-air maneuvers
Iridescent feathers casting a metallic sheen
Ruby-throated Hummingbird: Vibrant green upperparts with a ruby-red throat
Feeds on nectar while hovering with rapid wing beats
Rufous Hummingbird: Bright rufous (reddish-orange) feathers covering most of the body
Small size but capable of incredible aerial maneuvers
Green Violetear: Inhabits highland forests in Central and South America
Favors highland forests, often found above the canopy level
Long-tailed Jaeger: Streamlined body with exceptionally long central tail feathers
Breeds in Arctic tundra and winters at sea
Pomarine Jaeger: Known for aggressive hunting and kleptoparasitism
Heavy, powerful build with broad wings and stout body

Inhabits forests, parks, and residential areas
Florida Jay: Small, blue bird endemic to Florida with a white underbelly
Green Jay: Prominent black face mask with a white stripe above
Colorful bird with a unique plumage pattern of blue, green, and black
Dark-eyed Junco: Ground feeders, primarily feed on seeds
Slate-gray or brown, depending on region, with a white belly
Tropical Kingbird: Aggressive defender of its territory, even against much larger birds
Gray Kingbird: Breeds in coastal areas, mangrove swamps, and islands
Notable for its large head and a heavy, straight bill
Belted Kingfisher: Characteristic black band across the belly
Large, crested head with a stout, dagger-like bill
Green Kingfisher: Usually solitary, defends feeding territories fiercely
Bright green back with blue head
Pied Kingfisher: Black cap and nape, white face and throat
Ringed Kingfisher: Long, curved bill and white belly
Prominent, shaggy crest and powerful bill
White-breasted Kingfisher: Large head with a stout, reddish bill ideal for hunting fish and insects
Red-legged Kittiwake: Usually silent at sea, but noisy at breeding colonies
Small gull with a white body, gray back, and distinctive red legs
Horned Lark: Inhabits open fields and deserts where it forages for seeds and insects
Distinctive bright yellow face contrasts with its brown and black body markings
Pacific Loon: Waterbird with a long neck and thin neck
Striking breeding plumage with a black head, white stripes on neck, and checkered back
Mallard: Females sport mottled brown camouflage to hide from predators
Orange bill with a black tip
Western Meadowlark: Yellow-breasted with a distinctive black V on chest
Hooded Merganser: Excellent diver, uses serrated bill to catch fish and crustaceans
Red-breasted Merganser: Streamlined body with a distinctive shaggy crest on the head

Mockingbird: White breast with black wings and white spots
Inhabits open areas with sparse vegetation, from suburbs to countryside
Nighthawk: Renowned for its silent, swift flight during twilight
Clark Nutcracker: Strong flier, capable of covering long distances
Gray and black bird with a sharp, pointed bill
White-breasted Nuthatch: Slate blue-gray back with a stark white underpart
Nimble climber, often seen upside down on tree trunks
Baltimore Oriole: Feeds on fruit, nectar, and insects, aiding in flower pollination

Hooded Oriole: Prefers palm trees for nesting, using fibers to create hanging nests

Orchard Oriole: Orange-red body with black head, back, and tail

Scott Oriole: Inclined to arid landscapes with yucca plants, which are used for nesting

Ovenbird: Brown or grey with a distinctive head stripe
Forages on the ground for insects and spiders
Brown Pelican: Brown and gray plumage with a lighter neck and head
Breeds in colonies on islands and coastal cliffs
White Pelican: One of the largest flying birds
Performs impressively synchronized flight patterns with flock
Western-Wood Pewee: Feeds almost exclusively on flying insects, catching them in mid-flight
Sayornis: Found near water, such as rivers and lakes, across the Americas
Insectivorous, using acrobatic flights to catch prey
American Pipit: Inhabits open country from tundra to beaches
Slim, ground-dwelling bird with a streaked back and buffy sides
Whip-poor Will: Named for its continuous, haunting whip-poor-will call at night
Camouflaged plumage, large eyes for night vision
Horned Puffin: Nests in cliffs, skilled swimmer and diver
In winter, lives far out to sea, rarely seen near land
Common Raven: All-black plumage with a large, curved beak
Large, all-black bird with a thick neck and shaggy throat feathers
White-necked Raven: Highly opportunistic eater, including fruit, insects, and carrion
American Redstart: Song is a series of high-pitched, sweet notes
Geococcyx: Inhabits deserts and scrublands of the Southwestern United States
Distinctive 'coo-coo-coo' call, often in a descending series
Loggerhead Shrike: Predatory songbird, impales prey on thorns

Great-Grey Shrike: Dominant and territorial, often seen alone or in pairs
Inhabits open woodland, farmland, and scrub across Europe and Asia
Baird Sparrow: Songs are a mix of trills and buzzes
Rufous cap and streaked back help it blend into its surroundings
Black-throated Sparrow: Song is a clear, sweet series of whistles
Diet includes seeds and insects, can survive long periods without water
Brewer Sparrow: Distinctly marked brown cap atop its head
Chipping Sparrow: Rusty cap and striking face pattern
Clay-colored Sparrow: Prominent dark line extending through the eye
House Sparrow: Paler underparts contrasted with darker, browner upperparts
Field Sparrow: Longer tail, often edged with white
Small, pinkish bill distinguishing it from others
Fox Sparrow: Vibrant contrast between its dark head and white throat
Heavier set with rich rufous plumage
Grasshopper Sparrow: Light brown with a flat head
Minimalist, clean head pattern with a central crown stripe
Harris Sparrow: Warm brown wings with darker streaks
White cheeks creating a striking contrast with the black head
Henslow Sparrow: Tail relatively short, with fine, dark banding
Le-Conte Sparrow: Buff-orange facial pattern with a fine gray nape
Lincoln Sparrow: Pink legs and feet, less conspicuous in the underbrush
Moderately long tail with a rounded appearance
Nelson-Sharp-tailed Sparrow: Black bill sharply contrasting with lighter plumage
Sharp, pointed tail aiding in its nimble flight
Savannah Sparrow: Small, pinkish bill for picking seeds and insects
Seaside Sparrow: Dark, short bill suited to its omnivorous diet
Song Sparrow: Long, rounded tail often cocked upright
Richly streaked underparts with a central breast spot
Tree Sparrow: Dark legs and feet, adept for perching in varied foliage
Bright chestnut crown contrasting with its gray face
Vesper Sparrow: Crisp, chestnut shoulder patch visible in flight
White-crowned Sparrow: Pink or yellowish bill, varying with age and region
Distinctive black and white head stripes
White-throated Sparrow: Bill grayish, stout, and well-suited to seed foraging
Cape-Glossy Starling: Glossy plumage with a metallic sheen
Bank Swallow: Noticeable dark band across the chest
Brownish upperparts with slight gloss under sunlight
Barn Swallow: Nests in open barns and under bridges
Juveniles show paler underparts and less forked tails
Cliff Swallow: Dark, glossy blue-black upperparts with a contrasting pale underparts
Square-tailed with a buffy rump and white forehead patch
Tree Swallow: Social species, often nesting in large colonies
Frequently seen flying over water, catching insects mid-air
Scarlet Tanager: Prefers dense deciduous forests as habitats
Feeds on insects and fruit, often foraging high in the canopy
Summer Tanager: Females are mustard-yellow, with some greenish shades on the back
Entirely rose-red male with a slightly paler bill
Artic Tern: Famous for its long migratory journey, pole to pole
Black Tern: Juveniles have a barred appearance with a dark bill and legs
Feeds over water, catching insects and small fish
Caspian Tern: Diet consists mainly of fish, caught with spectacular plunge-dives
Nests on the ground on isolated beaches
Common Tern: Flight is buoyant and graceful, often hovering before diving for fish
Breeds in colonies on coasts, islands, and inland lakes
Elegant Tern: Long, thin bill with a slight curve
Feeds primarily on small fish, captured with precise aerial dives
Forsters Tern: Black cap in breeding season, white in winter
Least Tern: Smallest of American terns with a yellow bill and a black tip
Nests are simple scrapes in the sand, sometimes lined with shells or debris
Brown Thrasher: Vocal mimic with an extensive repertoire of songs and calls
Dense shrubbery and thickets are preferred habitats
Sage Thrasher: Smallest of the thrashers with a short, straight bill
Inhabits sagebrush flats, where it is often more heard than seen
Black-capped Vireo: Diminutive songbird with a distinctive black cap
Blue-headed Vireo: Sleek black bill complements its sharp profile
Philadelphia Vireo: Two white wing bars, adding to its delicate appearance
Red-eyed Vireo: Black bill, perfectly curved for precision
Two white wing bars, symbols of its aerial agility
Warbling Vireo: Olive-green above, with a subtle yellow-white below, mirroring early autumn hues
White-eyed Vireo: Yellow-green plumage, with a distinctive white eye-ring, a window to its soul
Yellow-throated Vireo: Song consists of clear, slurred notes
Bay-breasted Warbler: Mosaic of brown, black, and white, a testament to its complexity
Black-and-white Warbler: Yellow eyes, windows to a soul of the forest
Black cap and white throat, a classic contrast
Black-throated-Blue Warbler: White belly, the underbelly of a cloud
Blue and white plumage, a sky and cloud motif
Blue-winged Warbler: Song is a series of buzzing notes
Canada Warbler: Short, direct flight, feeds on insects
Chestnut-sided Warbler: Single white wingbar as a distinct mark
Golden-winged Warbler: Song is a series of buzzes and trills
Black mask and chest crescent for distinction
Hooded Warbler: White wing bars on black wings
Magnolia Warbler: Song is a sweet, varied warble
Yellow and grey plumage with black streaks
Mourning Warbler: Feeds on insects near the ground
Song is a mournful, slow trill
Myrtle Warbler: Features a long, black tail with distinctive white edges
Nashville Warbler: Small, with a yellow belly and dark legs
Orange-crowned Warbler: Subtle orange crown hidden in plumage
Two white wing bars for distinction
Palm Warbler: Noted for its yellow-brown or olive-brown plumage and white belly
Pine Warbler: Yellow throat and breast adding vibrancy
Adapted to life in the trees with a long, pointed bill
Prairie Warbler: Characterized by its yellow-green plumage with brown streaks
Its yellow throat brightens the white underparts
Prothonotary Warbler: Bright yellow body as a standout feature
Swainson Warbler: Long, curved bill useful for digging insects
Wilson Warbler: Features a black stripe through the eye and a white belly
Worm-eating Warbler: White belly complements two white wing bars
Two white wing bars for identification
Yellow Warbler: Equipped with a black bill, ideal for insectivory
Notable for a yellow breast adorned with black streaks
Northern Waterthrush: Sparrow-like bird with a distinct white throat and streaked underparts

Louisiana Waterthrush: Brown back with white streaks for camouflage
Bohemian Waxwing: Medium-sized with a distinctive crest and a black mask

Cedar Waxwing: Sleek appearance with a sociable nature
Yellow or orange beak contrasts with the black mask around its eyes
American-Three-toed Woodpecker: Black and white plumage with striking pattern

Red-bellied Woodpecker: Adaptable, often found in woodlands and suburban areas alike

White belly contrasting with black back
Bewick Wren: Black tail with a white tip for distinction

Carolina Wren: Rich brown plumage with a white belly
House Wren: Small and unassuming with a brown body and a white belly

Marsh Wren: Lives in wetlands, identified by streaked plumage and a loud song

Winter Wren: Small, brown bird with a round body
Known for its surprisingly loud song given its small size
Common Yellowthroat: Yellow and black plumage with a striking mask
